Given that under the existing system students who conscientiously object to paying the Student Guild fee nonetheless remain entitled to the benefits of membership of the Guild, it may reasonably be argued that offering the option of conscientious objection is sufficient compliance with the UDHR.

So I think that this sudden interest and support for international covenants by members of the Liberal Party is in fact misplaced. Those covenants do not support their arguments on this occasion. They have led no evidence in support of the assertion that they gain any support from those instruments. As I say, it is quite bizarre, given the attitude of senators opposite when we debated things like the UN declaration on religious beliefs and the UN declaration on children, that they now turn to those international organisations for support.

TALK.START.PARA: —We only did that for the Democrats' benefit.

—I think the Democrats would also be aware of the evidence that, in fact, those assertions are not supported and that highly qualified legal opinion has concluded that there is no problem with the current arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I do not really want to go through the whole debate about student unionism. I think it was well canvassed in Australian society in the 1970s. I think it is a shame that the student warriors who are now members of parliament have not been able to give up their ideological obsession with this issue. I understand that Mr Moore was also a well-known student politician on a tertiary campus in Western Australia. I think they are trying to fight the fights of the old days that were lost and have another go at them.

While I know that Senator Campbell has an ideological and deep personal commitment to what he sees as a question of voluntary membership, I think he is also coloured in his views, as he indicated in a couple of the speeches he has made, about the question of the NUS supported candidate in the federal seat of Swan at the last election. Senator Campbell, like many Liberals, has been unable to accept the result of the election and the fact that Mr Beazley was returned in the seat of Swan, and Mr Gear in the seat of Canning. His contribution today again highlighted the concern that nags away at him.

The reality is that the Labor Party won the federal seat of Swan in a close fought election. It was a seat that the Liberal Party expected to win; it did not. It is a very good result for the Australian parliament, as well as the Labor Party, that Mr Beazley was returned. I really do think it is time to move on. Senator Campbell has dealt with the arguments about voluntary student unionism. They really are not relevant. They do reflect an ideological obsession on behalf of the Liberal Party and some of its former student politicians. I think we ought to support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about a part of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill which requires the Commonwealth to deduct a payment to the states for tertiary education if there is voluntary unionism. It is all very well for Senator Chris Evans, who really added nothing to the debate at all, to claim that that debate was held in the past. The point I make to Senator Evans is that gross injustices still exist, and they demand some sort of remedial treatment in the form of making a student's decision to join a union an act of choice.

PARA.TAB: We had an extraordinary speech from Senator Bell who, no doubt, tried hard to put something together, but it had no direction or discipline at all. He also failed to realise the great injustice that is being imposed on the student body. Not only are students compelled to be part of a union—and that is the end of the matter—they are also compelled to pay a very large sum of money relative to their income or their assets.

My four children are graduates of the University of Queensland—one of the largest universities in this country. I objected to paying $600 or $800 or more a year for my children, when entitled to free education, to be part of what was clearly a nefarious organisation, as the student body at the University of Queensland was at the time. I took that up with the registrar. I rang him and said, `I object to paying student union fees on a compulsory basis for my children'. I was told in very gruff terms, `Like it or lump it. If you do not pay it, not only will your children not be allowed to enrol at the university, but they will not be allowed to sit for examinations. If they can get into the examinations on some basis, they certainly will not have their papers marked'.

I was not accommodated at all by the university administration. I did not push ahead with the matter because I have a very strong view, which I have always followed, that I am in public life and my wife and children are not. I certainly will not make them in any way captives of my political beliefs, and I certainly do not expect any member of my family to fight the political battles that I feel strongly about.

It is a gross injustice that students are forced to be members of unions. There is every case to be made for a voluntary union system. When I was an undergraduate I paid something like #5 to be a member of the student union and a member of the sports union. It is a very different situation today.

To say, as Senator Bell does, that facilities provided by the student unions are somehow a life support system that cannot be provided in any way by any other body and to compare them with local governments is so fatuous that I wonder whether he has ever been on a campus, or whether he has been at some second-rate TAFE in the backblocks of Tasmania. Anything that the student union does can be provided by private industry.

What do students want? The university buildings are provided by the government—or by the university itself, in the case of Bond University. The university is required to provide the roads, the lecturers, the lecture rooms, the hardware and the libraries. Basically, all one gets out of the student union is the opportunity to buy food—food which is often inedible and certainly not life promoting in any way. Food can be provided by anyone running a refectory. It can be provided by a formation from a group of students. But most of the students who are interested in student union affairs are interested in politics, not in commerce. There are absolutely no facilities that the student union claims to provide that cannot be provided by private industry.

If this were just a small matter of a few people saying, `You have to join a union and pay a couple of hundred bucks a year', that would be fine. But one has to look at the overall picture. The student unions on the big campuses have grown out of all perspective. They are giant organisations. As Senator Ellison said, they have budgets running into millions, and there is a lot of abuse. There is even criminal abuse at times in the administration of those funds. There is also an abuse, in a perverse sense, in so far as those funds are used to promote whatever political causes the executive group of the union holds at the time. They do that free from any censure by or consultation with the student body. The executives of student unions are absolutely uncontrollable by the great mass of the students that they represent.

The student unions now provide career opportunities. I was astonished to find some years ago that union presidents are now full-time paid employees. I believe that Mr Beazley was the first one in the guild in Western Australia to become a full-time paid president. I cannot understand how the needs of a student body demand a full-time paid president. If a student—an undergraduate or a graduate doing a higher degree—could not look after the affairs of that union movement, then there is something wrong. I say that as someone who has taught in universities in three different countries.

At the present time we often see a gross abuse of power in Australian student unions. They pursue issues that do not promote the welfare of the student body at all. Their efforts ought to be directed at improving the lot of students on the campuses, but instead they pursue issues—often to the detriment of the student body and sometimes to society—in which they simply should not be involved.

The trouble is that the ALP likes the student unions. It is not true to say, as Senator Bell said, that everyone in a student union is a Labor member. The point is, as I said before, that the ordinary student cannot influence the executive. The ALP likes the student unions because it has a rent-a-crowd which it can turn out on any controversial issue at any time. It can guarantee to turn it out and get good television footage at the time of an election.

In so far as these bodies are now uncontrollable and are not contributing to the welfare of the student movement, it should be a fundamental exercise of a student's basic rights to say whether he or she wishes to join a student union. If that happened, there would be a big change in the way the student unions performed: give some power back to the student body.

One of the good things about the introduction of HECS and some sort of fee system for students is that some power is given back to members of the student body. They can demand that inadequate lecturers perform and that bad administration of the university is dealt with, because they are making some contribution to their education through the payment of these fees. By the same token, if students can have a voluntary association with the student unions, there will be an improvement in the quality of administration and in the quality of service that those unions can provide. I support the opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to Senator Campbell and other members of the coalition that the debate today is really about the right of the Commonwealth to replace the loss of revenue which is essential for the provision of services to students in Western Australia. That is what the debate is about. I suggest that it is not the Commonwealth which is blackmailing Western Australian voters but the other way around.

PARA.TAB: This clause allows the government to recover funds from the states if those states have interfered with the autonomy of an institution—in this case it is a students' institution. It is states like Western Australia that are interfering with the autonomy of student institutions and not the other way around. If the Western Australian government begins to bleat because it has to pay for the consequences of its action, I will quote for its benefit a very wise saying, `If you sow the wind, then you will reap the whirlwind'.

I remind the Senate what services the students fees provide. In the two universities which I have been involved in in the last 5 1/2 years those fees provided a welfare officer. Mr Moore's very capable researcher Marc Dale, who was a student of the QUT, was the welfare officer at QUT for some years while I was there. He was one of the best welfare officers we ever had. He was a very committed member of the Liberal Party and a very committed member of the student guild at QUT.

TALK.START.PARA: —And voluntaryism.

—Of course it is. He told me that on the many occasions he has rung me in the last few weeks. He is a very committed student and a very good friend of mine. However, I was not convinced by his arguments. The services which are provided by student guilds include such things as welfare officers, child care facilities, education officers, sporting facilities, and so on. If Senator Panizza really understood what Senator Bell was saying he would have realised that these facilities are also provided by many local governments. That is where the comparison is made. I do not think Senator Panizza understood what Senator Bell was saying at that point.

PARA.TAB: We are arguing about the ability of students not only to be provided with these services but also to have some way of controlling and influencing the direction that these services take and which services should be provided. When I was involved in this debate some years ago I did some research. I talked to various vice chancellors and it was pointed out to me that if students do not pay these fees through their guild they will have to pay the fees in some other way because the services are essential in the mind of the universities.

The membership of the guild is not compulsory; it is the payment of the fee that is. If the fee is not paid through the guild it will be paid to the university in some other way. The membership of the guild provides the students with some control over the way in which their fees are spent. That is the essential thing that membership of the student guild provides. The fee for these services will be paid either through the guild or through the university in some other way. That is where the compulsion comes in. The membership of a guild enables the students to have some control. In other words, it enshrines that principle of individualism which is so important to the coalition.

I could have made a stronger argument than Senator Ellison did about the politicisation of guilds. This politicisation has come about not only through the interference of the Labor Party but also through the interference of the coalition in student politics. This is certainly the case in the two universities with which I have been involved—the University of Queensland and the Queensland University of Technology.

I would abhor that politicisation whether it came from the Labor Party or the coalition. I believe that is the one thing that cuts across the argument I am making about the fact that student guilds are there to provide representation and control over the services which are provided. I hear the argument Senator Ellison is making and I sympathise with it. The Democrats support what the Commonwealth is doing because it enables students to have representation and to have some control over the services which are provided.

One of the problems we have within universities at the moment is the apathy of students. Again I hear what the opposition is saying in that respect. I will give the Senate an illustration. In 1991—a year in which I took quite a deal of interest in the elections at the Queensland University—only 4,000 out of 20,000 students voted in the election for the student guild. That was the highest vote they ever had. At QUT in another year, 800 out of 20,000 students voted.

The problem is not whether students have to pay a fee: the problem really is that if students are not happy with the actions of their guilds they should exercise their democratic prerogative. Where democracy is falling down is not whether the payment of fees to student unions or student guilds are voluntary but where students are not voting and taking their places in the activities of the particular associations to which they belong.

We want to support the continuation of these services and the continued funding of these services. The coalition needs to activate its own student movement, get it working and make sure that those students who support its particular opinions are able to make their presence felt within the student unions and student guilds to which they belong. They need to have a say in the way in which these services are provided because they are essential and must be funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few brief remarks on this contentious issue. I was interested in the comments made by Senator Woodley. He said, probably with some reason, that he deplores the politicisation which occurs in student unions or, as Senator Bell would have it, student local governments. But, nonetheless, I think that is a problem.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley drew this concern to the attention of the Senate in a quite proper way. Then surprisingly he concluded by saying that the way to deal with this problem is for more students, and particularly those from the conservative side of politics, to get more involved in these student activities. In other words, this would further politicise these unions and guilds. The solution that Senator Woodley presented to the chamber would compound the problem.

There was also an assumption—and I think that this is important—that these services would not be provided if they were voluntary. When we think about that, we are saying that these services are absolutely vital to the students but that, if the students wanted to pay for them, they would not be. I really do not think Senator Woodley is able to have it both ways. If he rests his case by saying that these things must be provided, they will be provided and they can only be provided in a compulsory fashion. Implicit in that argument is the possibility that students do not want the comprehensive range of services which are on offer. I do not know the answer to that question. One of the advantages of bringing in a more sensitive response to market forces is to test what is absolutely vital to the students and what is not. There is a problem of logic there, and I do not think that has been addressed by any of the supporters of this bill.

I would like to draw Senator Bell's remarks to the attention of the Senate. I thought he tried to use some language to get around the fact that these student unions were not unions in the industrial sense. Whereas one can point to activities which are not typical of trade unions, nonetheless, as the saying goes, if it looks like a duck, waddles like a duck and quacks like a duck, there is a presumption in law that it probably is a duck. I do not think we should get buried in semantics, but most of these bodies call themselves unions and we should basically accept that.

However, `union' is not the key word. The key word is `voluntary'. I would have thought that all Australians would have found this word very congenial. They have the choice as to whether or not they join this union. If Senator Bell asked the Australian public whether they believe in compulsory trade unionism, they would say that they do not. They want to have a choice of whether they join a particular trade union or not. Given the history of Senator Bell's party, it was a pity that he skated over the importance of the word `voluntary'.

The other point I would like to raise with Senator Bell is that for some 10 years his party was a strong supporter of voluntary unionism. He may be able to correct me, but in this chamber some two years ago his party voted with us to tackle the issue—
Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bell is able to correct the record, I think he should because it is quite important. He skated over his previous history on this issue. Maybe it was Senator Bell who voted with us to try to prevent compulsory student unionism. In that case, I would urge him to go back to the arguments that he used in those days to support our position. Nonetheless, he has conceded the nub of my point—that he has reversed his previous position on this quite important issue which is before the chamber today.

PARA.TAB: A pattern is now emerging with the Australian Democrats. On another occasion we had very strong support for small business and farmers opposing the removal of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. His party was very strong in tackling the problem of big unions. In recent years the whole thrust of Senator Bell's party's policy has been dropped. Unfortunately, it was dropped and modified at the very time he came into this position as the Democrats' industrial relations spokesperson. I think that is a pity.

The community is starting to learn that Senator Bell's party, under Senator Kernot, will tend to support the power and privileges of unions. I think that is a great pity. I suggest to Senator Bell that it is out of line with the way most of his supporters feel. Although this is not a particularly important bill, in the sense that it does not affect vast numbers of Australians, it would have gone better for Senator Bell if he had stuck to his previously stated position on this. The fact is that he has reversed his position.

Some thoughtful comments were made by Senator Chris Evans on this issue. I was interested in his comments because he raised the issue of international conventions and covenants and how they should affect Australian law. He said that the Western Australian education minister said that we should look at an international covenant which he felt may have applied to this bill. Given the nature of the arguments that we constantly hear from the Labor Party and the Democrats on the need to be more attuned to international treaties and covenants, he raised an interesting argument. Undoubtedly, he put that argument forward in an attempt to show that the sorts of things which are important to the Labor Party are also consistent with the general thrust of this bill.

An important issue before this chamber is how much Australian law should be influenced by UN treaties—treaties which have never been endorsed by the Australian people and Australian parliaments. The argument is constantly put forward that `this law must be put in place' or `that law must be put in place' because there is a UN treaty—signed by Senator Gareth Evans or Mr Keating but not passed by this parliament—which says it must.

This is an interesting issue. As Senator Schacht has indicated, these treaties do erode the sovereignty and independence of our nation. It always surprises me that the Senator Evanses and Mr Keatings of this world, the great republicans of this nation, so constantly talk about the independence of Australia—which as a strong supporter of our current constitution, I ardently support—while at the same time taking steps which erode the sovereignty and independence of our nation by following these UN treaties and instruments. The ability of Australian citizens to take complaints out of Australia to UN committees is a very significant change in the nature of law in this country and certainly overturns the Australia Act, which was brought in by a Labor government only five years ago.

Senator Chris Evans raised a useful point. We have signed so many of these instruments and signed so many of these treaties that no-one really knows what is contained in all these inevitable clauses. One day they may well come back to haunt the Labor Party. Mr Goss, the Premier of Queensland, was very aware of that. It is true that there are ILO conventions which talk about freedom of association and voluntary unionism. If our party ever decided to use such a convention, we could wipe out the closed shops in this country. We would destroy much of the basis of the compulsory membership of trade unions. That is why I say to Labor Party members who may be prepared to follow Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Keating down this UN path that it may come back to haunt them, particularly from that base of support which they so constantly need and rely on.

I think it was useful for Senator Chris Evans to bring this matter to the chamber. Whatever legal opinions he may have been able to adduce, the essential issue of whether Australian law should be controlled and directly influenced by UN treaties is an important issue and undoubtedly a topic which will be returned to on a number of other occasions in the forthcoming months.

I strongly support the arguments that my colleagues have put forward so well, to be quite frank. There is an issue of principle here. Principle is always difficult for the Labor Party to deal with, because it is a party that has very few principles. Nonetheless, the principle that was so well expressed by Senator Campbell and Senator Ellison is important; that is, the need for people to have choice and not to be forced to join unions. I strongly support their remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised to hear some of the comments in this debate today from the other side and from Senator Bell on behalf of the Australian Democrats. This debate is capable of being reduced to very simple terms. The debate is about whether the Commonwealth government should have the power to reduce the grant to any given state because that state has said to its students, `You will have a choice as to whether or not you join a student union'. The government wishes to say that, if a state government gives students free choice, it should have its states grant reduced. We in the National and Liberal parties disagree.

PARA.TAB: For all of the rhetoric and the sophistry that we have heard from the other side and from the Democrats, it is an immutable fact that those of us in the National and Liberal parties are supporting free speech and freedom of association. More importantly, we do not believe that the Commonwealth government should have an overreaching power to dictate to the state governments how their money should be spent, because that is effectively what happens. A state government that gives students free choice as to whether they want to join a union has its states grant reduced and the money given to a student union. In effect, the Commonwealth is allocating that money for them.

Nowhere in the constitution can I find any provision that says that the Commonwealth government should have a power in relation to an untied grant to direct that money and not to give it to the relevant state government. This is what this provision is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tying untied grants.

—Yes, tying untied grants. It is a very dangerous precedent for this chamber to support the bill that the government has brought before it. It is a very dangerous precedent for this chamber not to support the amendment moved by the Liberal and National parties here today. If we do not support the coalition's amendment, then what we effectively say is that from now on the Commonwealth government can dictate to state governments on any issue of policy on the basis that if the state government takes a certain course of action the Commonwealth will take away more of its money—take away more of its untied grant and spend it for it. It destroys the whole concept of the states having a right to exercise power in their own state.

PARA.TAB: Nowhere in the constitution did our founding fathers say that the Commonwealth should have a power to dictate how states spend their money in the valid exercise of those state powers. That is what this debate is about. It is about whether we support coercion—both by the federal government over the state governments and by student unions over individuals—or whether we really believe in freedom and free choice.

It is quite interesting that in the past some of the people who have spoken in this debate have supported some of the most spurious claims about a right to do this and a right to do that. Yet they are now saying that there should be no right for students to choose whether or not they want to belong to a student union. Senator Kemp has very eloquently said today that if we follow the arguments of Senator Bell and the government and believe that the services provided by student unions are invaluable—that they cannot be done without—then, of course, the students would happily cough up the money and join the student union. It seems to us that the only people who really believe that those services are so invaluable are the members of the government, the members of the Democrats and some members of the executives of the student unions in question, because, given a chance, the students themselves do not see it that way.

Let me make a brief comment about when I was at university, which was not that long ago. We did not have compulsory student unionism. The first thing I did when I got to university, quite interestingly enough, was to join the Oxford Union Society. But it was not a union; it was a debating society. There was an Oxford University students union but my junior common room in my college chose not to have anything at all to do with the Oxford University students union. Our junior common room was non-political. We had absolutely no interest in politics and we certainly had absolutely no interest in the Oxford University students union.

The good thing about it, I suppose, was that we did not see much of the executive of the Oxford University students union because most of them were busy being involved in die-ins outside Greenham Common and riots in the centre of London. They certainly were not representing our viewpoint; they were not doing the sorts of things that we were interested in. So we said, `We don't want to have anything to do with it'. And do you know what? The amazing thing is that Oxford University continued on undeterred, our junior common room continued on undeterred, and I was not disadvantaged in the slightest because I was not a member of the Oxford University student union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you need counselling?

—I did not need counselling; I did not need someone to hold my hand; and I did not need a special lesbian and homosexual room set up for my benefit. This is what many of these student unions now get involved in; nothing but the crassest and most idiotic politics and, most importantly, the politics of the extremist fringe.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that the Australian university students are no different from this. The Australian populace on the whole does not believe in compulsion when it comes to unionism, be it in the university or in the workplace. So why is it that this chamber today seems poised to support compulsion and to support coercion—coercion by a wicked and pernicious federal government and by student unions which cannot, given free choice, attract funds from students who are increasingly dissatisfied and disenchanted with their idiotic politics?

TALK.START.PARA: —There were some points that I wanted to address but which I did not get time to in my first contribution. The first one is in response to the interjection of Senator McMullan that we did not support the state government this time last year because we chose to support state governments that are Liberal governments. Clearly, had we wanted to use the tactics this government is using to bribe or induce the Western Australian government not to do what it is doing in relation to voluntarism on campus, we would have moved an amendment this time last year to penalise a state government to in fact ensure that there was compulsion on campus. Of course, we did not do that.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan would know that it certainly would not be our policy to create a similar form of bribery in relation to a state government to cause it to adopt some other form of policy. Our action here is intended to ensure that any government across Australia that seeks to take any action in relation to compulsion or voluntarism in relation to student membership is not penalised either way. That is the principle.I think Senator O'Chee actually hit the nail on the head. This is the first time that I know of in my experience, which is only brief, that the government is actually using an untied general purpose grant and saying that it is going to tie it; that is, if a state does not do this particular action the government will take money away from it.

I think the Democrats are going along with a very dangerous precedent. I understand, even though I do not agree with them, their views about unions on campus. Of course, they are arguments I have heard for many years. They are in fact arguments we have within the Liberal Party. We have had some very bitter battles with what were known as the `guildies' within the party—some of the people who had become involved in the guild. Michael Leishman, who was a guild president, if I remember correctly—I hope I do not hurt him—used to speak at our state conferences very much in favour of the very arguments Senator Robert Bell has used. He said that it is not a union; it is more of a local government-type situation. We used to have very good debates at our state conferences and Young Liberals conferences and so forth. We usually won by about 500 votes to 4, but we always had good debates.

I have heard those arguments before and I do not agree with them. As I said earlier, that is really not the point of the debate here. As Senator McMullan said by way of interjection, Western Australian students will get freedom of association. It is just a question of how much it will cost the Australian taxpayer.

That brings me to my next point, one that has yet to be addressed: as student guilds or associations come to rely more and more upon federal government moneys to subsidise their membership revenue, they will become more and more reliant upon the discretion of the federal minister. In the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, which I have not read since last year but which is still sharply focused in my mind, the specific clause about how the money goes to the student unions or institutions clearly set out, I believe, that it was a matter of ministerial discretion.

I think an issue this chamber will have to deal with sooner or later, probably within the next 12 months, is under what regulations and criteria that money is given to student unions. Take the extreme and probably stupid and silly example of a campus with thousands of people, only a few—10 or 15—of whom are members of the union. Clearly, that would be an outrageously unrepresentative student union. I am sure that any sensible minister—and we have some sensible ministers—would not want to pay millions of dollars to such a student organisation that was clearly unrepresentative. So in that position the minister will have to make some sort of decision on whether or not the government gives millions of dollars to student unions. That is one worry, and we will have to deal with that. There will have to be regulations to decide what sorts of unions we want to fund.

The funding will start flowing from Commonwealth taxpayers' money and ministers will have to make decisions. Let us hope the decisions are made in a slightly more open, accountable and transparent way than were Minister Kelly's decisions on sporting grants. That is a very real worry.

This will become a matter of ministerial discretion. Decisions will have to be made here in Canberra about whether or not the unions get taxpayers' money. So the unions themselves will become more and more reliant on the fiat of the government in Canberra and therefore become, I guess, less independent and less able to express views that may be in opposition to a federal government. That should be a matter of concern.

If this provision does make it through today, if we are not successful in deleting clause 20 from the bill, as sure as night follows day—to use a hackneyed cliche—this will become an issue we will have to deal with. Money will flow to unions from Canberra; we will be taking money away from Australian taxpayers and sending it to student unions; and they will lose some of that independence that I am sure the Democrats would like to see retained.

I now address some of the comments made by Senator Woodley, particularly what he described as the state government interfering in the autonomy of institutions. If that is the case, what the state government of Western Australia, and in particular my good friend and colleague the Hon. Norman Moore, the minister, are doing is ensuring that individuals do have the freedom to choose not to join a union. If that is called interfering in the autonomy of institutions, so be it. If a government needs to ensure that a young Australian does have that freedom when he or she goes to campus, so be it: that is interference.

If we have to interfere to ensure that when 16- or 17-year-old Australians, Western Australians in particular, go to the University of Western Australia, Curtin University, Murdoch University or any of the other campuses around the place they are not confronted with a big sign on the front of the university saying `no ticket, no start' or `no guild membership fees, no degree', I think it is a very good idea for us to do so and to pull that sign down. But, again, that is me putting my view on student union voluntarism. The issue before us—and I plead with Senator Bell to see it this way—is whether or not we should be pouring taxpayers' money into student unions and, as Senator O'Chee said, tying untied grants.

On the issue of whether the services provided by unions are seen as valuable or not valuable by the students who should use those services, Senator Woodley referred to Mark Dale, who works on the staff of the minister, Norman Moore, and who is a very strong advocate of voluntary student unionism. He has worked very hard on this issue since he has been on the staff of Norman Moore and I believe that he has spoken to Senator Woodley as a friend on these issues.

It is interesting to note that Mark was a welfare officer on the campus he was on. One of the arguments used by, I am sure, the Democrats and those who oppose us on voluntary student unionism is that the counselling and welfare services provided by the guild are some of the most important. I do not seek to enter into that argument, but the fact of the matter is that Mark Dale has been a welfare officer on campus. He knows probably better than anybody in this chamber how important the duties of a welfare officer are. Yet Mark Dale is saying, `Voluntary student unionism is vital'.

I think that refutes in some way Senator Woodley's use of Mark Dale as some sort of reference because he was a welfare officer on the campus in Queensland. DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill, which is substantially in line with what the coalition has been advocating for some time and, clearly, in some parts, is in direct response to coalition pressure. However, I would like to comment on some of the main provisions of the bill and, at the same time, indicate the coalition attitude to it.

PARA.TAB: This is the third and final set of amendments to the ATSIC Act flowing from recommendations contained in ATSIC's review report to the minister which was tabled in parliament earlier this year. This review was carried out as a requirement under section 26 of the ATSIC Act 1989, the principal act covering that organisation.

It proposes amendments to that act which will, firstly, establish the Torres Strait Regional Authority to replace the existing Torres Strait Regional Council with the objective of cutting down on the volume of duplication with ATSIC and other bodies operating in the Torres Strait Islands. Secondly, it will devolve some financial functions to the regional councils but will try to ensure that there will also be safeguards to deal with the regional councils that do not perform properly. Thirdly, it will establish the Electoral Review Panel. Fourthly, it will strengthen the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit.

The provisions in the bill for the Torres Strait regional authorities propose the establishment of an independent Torres Strait Regional Authority to replace the current Torres Strait Regional Council. These provisions occupy a major part of the bill. The Torres Strait Regional Authority will be established as a body corporate and will operate in much the same way as ATSIC. The provisions cover things such as: funding powers, including the appointment of advisory committees and the disclosure of pecuniary interests; the provision of 20 elected members and election procedures; the appointment of a general manager by the minister; staff appointments; and reporting requirements, such as estimates of expenditure, annual reports and financial statements.

While the coalition recognises the practicality and advantages of rationalising multiple government input into the Torres Strait, we understand from visits there that many people living in the Torres Strait Islands have aspirations towards a type of self-determining rule similar to Norfolk Island or the Cook Islands. The coalition's support of these rationalisation measures does not reflect support for some form of independence, and certainly not for sovereignty.

There are problems with some of the proposals in that there are people who have lived in the Torres Strait Islands for some time who are not indigenous people. I give the examples of members of the European, Chinese and Japanese populations. Rather than making a set of laws for one section of the population, we feel that there should be no blank cheque given by these proposals.

This is not a purely federal concern; it also involves the Queensland state government. That complicates the debate somewhat. To some extent, these proposals would need to get through state laws dealing with police and schools, and that needs to be taken into account. Whilst we are supportive, we appreciate that the islanders wish to maintain their cultural integrity and want their own body outside ATSIC. However, at this stage, we emphasise that the coalition is not making a commitment to sovereignty.

As regards the devolution of powers to the regional council, this bill strengthens reporting arrangements and accountability requirements for those regional councils. It provides them with increased funding responsibilities with wider powers to approve funds and issue guarantees. These powers may also be suspended if deemed necessary by the ATSIC chairman. The regional councils will now be required to provide draft budgets which are tied to a regional plan for their region. ATSIC will have the power to remove regional councillors who fail to perform functions or comply with budgetary or reporting requirements.

The coalition wishes to comment that this devolution of power to regional councils comes from the ATSIC bureaucracy, which should cut back its size. I would hope that this means that the money saved can be put towards projects on the ground so that the money gets to the people who need it for essential services. The coalition welcomes these moves.

We also welcome moves in the bill which strengthen the power of ATSIC to deal with those who do not perform satisfactorily. This is essential in any organisation, regardless of size, in order to achieve peak performance and optimum accountability. It is important to remember that a crucial aspect of self-determination resting with regional councils lies in their function to allocate funding. Perhaps it is testimony to their success in handling this role that a large number of complaints against them are from those who have failed to convince the regional councils of their eligibility for funding. In other words, they do not distribute money willy-nilly.

This bill will also significantly expand the Office of Evaluation and Audit to include regular audit and evaluation of ATSIC, Aboriginal Hostels Limited, the Commercial Development Corporation and the Torres Straight Regional Authority. It also provides the mechanism to allow the minister or ATSIC to request the evaluation and audit of particular aspects of operation of regional councils, any individual, body corporate or unincorporated body receiving one or more grants or loans from ATSIC, and any borrowers whose loans have been guaranteed by ATSIC.

It would be the coalition's intent in government to review where the Office of Evaluation and Audit is actually situated within the structure of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to make it even more independent. But we are pleased that the government has finally moved—obviously under pressure from the opposition—to require organisations receiving funding from ATSIC to be accountable for the allocation of that funding.

There are also other areas of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations receiving government funds through other mechanisms which are not touched by this legislation, and therefore not subject to this added scrutiny. The coalition would like to see the same scrutiny applied to those outside the ATSIC funding umbrella. We would also like to ensure that the function of the Office of Evaluation and Audit is not conducted on an ad hoc basis with auditing and evaluation requests merely conducted at the whim of the minister or the commission, which is how this bill is set up.

It is therefore our intention to move an amendment—and I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage of the bill—which requires the Office of Evaluation and Audit to perform regular evaluation and audit of those receiving funding through ATSIC. The object of our amendment is not just to provide the option for audit and evaluation, but to make this a requirement. Obviously the amount of work that this will involve will vary according to the nature of the organisation and the size of the grant or funding. Importantly, organisations will be held accountable for their actions, and this is no more nor less than we would expect in any area of government expenditure.

The fourth item to be dealt with by this bill is the Electoral Review Panel. The purpose of this section is to review boundaries and the groupings of the regions and wards, and review the electoral system generally, reporting to the minister, and ensuring that such a review is independent and objective. There have been criticisms that the arrangements for the December elections have been carried out too hastily, without adequate consultation, particularly in relation to the planned system of wards.But the coalition is in favour of the Electoral Review Panel which will have ample time for consultation and planning prior to the next set of elections.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, the bill is substantially in line with what the coalition has been advocating for some time. Whilst we do not oppose the bill, I have taken the opportunity to constructively highlight areas for further improvements. We make the point that we do not see the setting up of the Torres Strait Regional Authority as a commitment of any sort to separate sovereignty. We flag our possible intent in government to move the Office of Evaluation and Audit out of ATSIC. I will be moving an amendment which will cover the other parts of our concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993. One of the most important amendments proposed in this bill creates a separate Torres Strait Regional Authority which will now have powers and functions similar to ATSIC in relation to Aboriginals and Islanders in the Torres Strait. The Senate is debating such an amendment for the second time. Four years ago when ATSIC legislation was before the Senate, the coalition moved amendments to give the Torres Strait Islanders separate recognition in a regional council. This amendment gives the Islanders their own form of ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: For a government which casts itself in the role of leading a reconciliation process, it has been very strong on rhetoric yet very slow to do the obvious—it has taken up to four years just to do the things it had to do for the Torres Strait. Following my question in the Senate earlier this week to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Ray, it is now on the public record that the federal government has opened a dialogue with the Torres Strait Islanders on the means to achieve greater self-government. Following discussions between the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and Torres Strait Islanders, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wrote to the Queensland Premier and the Torres Strait Island Coordinating Council to propose a preliminary meeting.

The bill before us today is seen by the Islanders as just a first step towards a form of self-government, having free association with Australia. It is, therefore, relevant to anticipate what those future steps might involve and what support is to be given to them by state and federal governments. There is a lot of confusion within the government ranks about the level of commitment to Torres Strait self-government. On Wednesday Senator Ray said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are many complex issues that would have to be discussed before this matter could be brought to fruition one way or the other, including the philosophical concept of whether it is the correct thing to do even before we settle the details.
Yet an article in the Australian on 5 November entitled `Islander self-governing by 2001: Tickner' states:

Visiting the Torres Strait to discuss moves for greater self-determination with island leaders and community groups, Mr Tickner told the Australian self-government by 2,001 was "highly likely" provided Torres Strait residents established a uniform goal.

It is obvious that the Aboriginal and Islander affairs minister has already committed himself and the government to seeing this process through. Meanwhile, Senator Robert Ray and the rest of the cabinet are left behind to muse over whether it is the correct thing to do or not—I include Senator Collins in this; I wish he would pay attention.

PARA.TAB: The Chairman of the Cape York Land Council, Mr Noel Pearson, seems to know more about the commitment given to the islands by Mr Tickner than the rest of the government. In an interview with Paul Lyneham on 10 November, Mr Lyneham asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and your statement today that Mabo has laid the basis for some future form of self-government within the nation—that's going to unsettle the horses as well, isn't it?
Mr Pearson replied:

It is nothing to be alarmed about. There's discussions particularly taking place in the Torres Strait where the real agenda is self-determination for the indigenous people of that region. You have to recall the fact that there are self-determination arrangements.

Senator Ray was at pains to explain that self-government for the Torres Strait was a long-term aspiration and the substantial details of the proposal by the Islanders have not yet been put forward. Yet only yesterday the Chairman of the ICC, Mr Gaetano Lui, told ABC radio that the ball was fairly in the government's court. Both federal and Queensland governments had been sent their proposals. Mr Lui complained about the lack of response from the state minister, Anne Warner. The desire for self government by the year 2001 was also expressed in the regional council's Torres Strait development plan. The Islanders believe they have reached a negotiating stage with the government. Mr Lui said that the time for consultation is over.

PARA.TAB: Mabo has given Islanders a position of strength, and the federal minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders has led them to believe that the government is right behind their self-government aims. Having had the Mabo glory taken away from him by the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker), Mr Tickner is now seeking political glory on his own. The problem is, as Senator Ray pointed out, that there are many complex issues to be discussed. In his enthusiasm to make a name for himself, Mr Tickner may be guilty of overlooking these complexities and, indeed, the welfare of the Islanders themselves.

Gaetano Lui has mentioned that the Islanders were looking to learn from various types of self-government, such as that used by the Cook Islands and Norfolk Island, in setting up their own form of self-determination which, in his words, would then become a model for Aboriginal people—I think we could say Islander people. I have been invited to the islands many times and I have spent much time with Gaetano and his family, including Mr Gaetano Lui senior, one of the true elder statesmen of the island. I have always been greeted with great warmth and hospitality. I have visited many of the Torres Strait Islands and talked with the elders and councillors. Gaetano is a personal friend of mine, and he has sent me the regional council's decision and recommendations on self-government.

The first step is accomplished by today's bill—the setting up of a separate regional authority for the Torres Strait Islands. The second stage is the devolution of other Commonwealth funds for services in the Torres Strait to the new authority. The third stage is the devolution of the Queensland government's funds for services in the Torres Strait to the new authority. I quote from the regional council's recommendation:

SPEECH.PARA: The next stage will be to include the standard government function of maintaining peace, good order and government, ultimately leading the authority to become an essential model for a centralised form of government having free association with Australia.

What person amongst us does not yearn to be master of his own destiny, to control the forces around us to our own liking and beliefs? It is understandable that the Torres Strait Islanders wish to distinguish themselves from the Aboriginal-dominated ATSIC. The coalition has always supported them on this view. I claim it an honour that I moved an amendment when the ATSIC bill went through, and I had the support of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is understandable that the Islanders should wish to take part in streamlining and making delivery of government services to the Torres Strait more efficient and useful. But is the desire for self-government, with free association with Australia, going to allow the Islanders to control events around them to their liking? What significant restraints on their activities will they lose? What freedoms will come from free association with Australia?

Gaetano Lui has mentioned the Cook Islands several times as a possible model for self-government. Firstly, it is important to remember that the Cook Islands were only ever New Zealand's to administer on behalf of the United Nations until the act of self-determination in 1965. The Torres Strait Islands, on the other hand, are as much a part of Australia as is Sydney or Melbourne; they are as much a part of the state of Queensland as is Mount Isa or the Gold Coast. Norfolk Island is a quite separate case. It was not part of a state but was a federal territory. The legal and constitutional implications of setting up self-government with free association with Australia are quite different, and in the case of the Torres Strait Islands would be very cumbersome. Norfolk Island was originally inhabited by Pitcairn Islanders, who in those days had no association with Australia. They do not consider themselves as part of Australia.

Unless the Queensland government relinquishes the Torres Strait Islands to the Commonwealth as a territory, a referendum would be necessary to set up another state. The regional council's aim of providing the standard government function of maintaining peace, good order and government, suggests a reference to a territory or a state rather than a local government. I have been advised that the Islanders' call for self-government, based on free association with Australia, goes far beyond the Norfolk Island model, and it suggests an even more autonomous state being not part of Australia.

The Islanders say they would still want Australia to look after foreign affairs and defence. This is like the Cook Islands, where they have their own parliament and free association with New Zealand. There are some 17,000 Cook Islanders living on the islands and another 20,000 in New Zealand. Income is mostly from tourism and remittances from relatives in New Zealand. The New Zealand government provided budget support in terms of a cash grant of $8.5 million—that is not a lot of money—in 1992-93 and $8.3 million this year. There is also an allocation for projects and training assistance, which was $5.5 million in 1992-93 and $5.2 million this year. They also receive several smaller packages from places such as the United Nations, Australia, the US, and so on, but they would not add up to much more than $1 million.

The budgetary support for health, education and social service is being phased out. There is a commitment to self-reliance by the year 2008, when New Zealand will no longer be required to give the Cook Islanders any budgetary assistance. The Cook Islanders are moving steadily towards independence, with all the responsibility and financial problems that will entail.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Gabble could stop for about 30 seconds, I would finish this answer. The report notes an apparent decline in port related charges, which, importantly, includes those levied by the state controlled port authorities. However, it attributes this fall primarily to an increase in the number of containers exchanged per ship visit rather than a change in the underlying level of the charges.

While the current index provides further evidence that the total costs of moving international cargo across the Australian waterfront have clearly and substantially fallen, the government fully recognises the need for continuing reform, particularly in port authorities and other services at the sea-land interface. In order to pursue this, I have provided Peter Morris, the chairman of the House of Representatives standing committee, with a further reference for that committee to inquire on an ongoing basis into the issues raised in the Warehouse to wharf report about improving performance of the sea-land interface.

The committee has been asked to give particular attention to encouraging participants in the transport system, and particularly the shippers, to recognise their role in improving overall performance. In this regard, the BTCE report provides detailed information which will assist shippers to understand the waterfront industry and raise their awareness of the costs involved in each separate link of the cargo handling chain.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. The minister claimed in question time yesterday that the awarding of Australian artists creative fellowships is `resolved at arm's length from the government'. Is it true that in 1989 the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, attended the meeting at which the recipients of that year's fellowship awards were decided and that one of the recipients was his personal friend Mr Geoffrey Tozer? Is it true, as alleged in a Sunday Herald-Sun in July 1991, that the first fellowship to Mr Tozer was to renovate the St Benedict's convent in Queanbeyan for the purpose of setting up a music school—a project that was personally overseen by Mr Keating? Why, if no music school eventuated and the building is to be sold on 27 November, has Mr Tozer received an unprecedented second fellowship valued at $325,000 when the guidelines for the Keating fellowships state that second fellowships should be awarded only in exceptional circumstances?

—This is all a wonderful, headline grabbing, sad story of failing to recognise that Australian artists and the arts community believe that the Keatings are a very significant initiative in the support of arts and that the decision that was made to award this grant this year to Mr Tozer was made by a committee of distinguished Australians at arm's length from the government who were aware of the guidelines to which Senator Patterson refers. I acknowledge that, as far as I can recall, she describes them accurately.

PARA.TAB: These people are aware of them. They judged a large number of high quality applicants and made the decision that the recipients as outlined in the announcements were those most appropriate to receive them. I have no reason to doubt the integrity of those people in the making of that decision. I have no reason to expect that any of those Australian citizens acted other than properly.

I was not there and the Prime Minister was not there. The meeting took place. I do not know the nature of the discussion that took place; it would be inappropriate for them even to tell me. All I know is that a committee has been established about which, as far as I know, no criticism has been raised as to its objectivity. That committee is chaired by the chair of the Australia Council.

I made a couple of appointments to the committee this year and I am not aware that they have been the cause. Nobody has given me any indication that people have any desire to reflect on the integrity of those two distinguished Australian artists in the craft area and in the dance area. For that reason, the decision this year stands quite separate from any sleazy attempt to imply that somehow this is an improper decision.

I have never heard of a report that says that the grant was made to build some music institution. I am aware that Mr Tozer was associated with that but, to the best of my knowledge, the terms of the award were not related to that matter. He is a citizen and he is entitled to carry out those activities. Whether he does or not is of no interest or consequence to me. But to the best of my knowledge, the application which was made, which I have not seen—it goes to the committee quite independently—was related to his performance schedule and his recording schedule during the period in which he was a recipient of the fellowship, and his application on this occasion for the second round of grants similarly related to a continuation of his outstanding record of performance and recording, being internationally recognised as an outstanding concert pianist.

I think it is a decision that will stand scrutiny as a proper recognition of an outstanding Australian artist. The nine people on the committee, who are honest Australians, should not have their reputations impugned so lightly. I know that those opposite come in to do that lightly, but I do not believe those citizens will take it lightly.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the thrust of Senator Patterson's question was, in essence, whether the Prime Minister interfered in the selection process which, in turn, impugns motives by suggesting that the people who were appointed to that board did not exercise independent and correct judgment. —Order! I am not changing the ruling.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What is the government doing to implement its commitment to broadening the selection procedure for the judiciary?
—I thank Senator Carr for what is, once again, a very timely—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is not only a lie, but it is offensive as well and I ask you to require him to withdraw it.

—Strictly, I do not think it is unparliamentary.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to recent media comment with regard to a dispute between the Western Australian Minister for Health, Mr Peter Foss, and the AMA over the issue of homebirths. What discussions has the minister had with Mr Foss with regard to midwife managed births and other alternatives to births in traditional hospital settings?

—Mr Foss is an enthusiastic supporter of the homebirth movement and he has proposed over recent weeks that midwifery be provided to the women of Western Australia by making it Medicare rebatable. I was in Perth last week and met Mr Foss to discuss funding for midwife managed births and the concern that it remain an affordable option for people.

PARA.TAB: The first point I made to Mr Foss was that the current Commonwealth policy is not to rebate the midwifery service and there is no proposal to change that policy. However, what I put to Mr Foss was a creative solution to that problem. I think it will be very satisfactory as it meets the needs of women to make a choice about giving birth.

I have been concerned about this matter because Western Australia is well behind in spending its money under the alternative birthing problem. This year it will have allocated to it $674,000. That includes $448,000 of unspent funds rolled over from two previous years. In Western Australia it is not spending its money on alternative birthing and that is a concern particularly as Mr Foss is wanting ways in which to assist women with the alternative birthing program.

It is a concern that many women who have contacted me directly and certainly contacted Mr Foss are not able to have the option of a choice of birth in Western Australia because of the unspent money under the alternative birthing program and because of obstruction by the AMA in that state. I was pleased to propose to Mr Foss that there are ways in which, under the allocation of alternative birthing money, salaried midwives can be appointed to hospitals with the opportunity to work in the hospital and also in the community to assist women to have homebirths if that is their choice.

That program is now being piloted in South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania. It is available to women in northern parts of Western Australia and the Northern Territory. So the model is well under way. It is a perfectly constructive and useful way of using the allocation from the Commonwealth to Western Australia and also assisting women in their choice in giving birth.

Mr Foss was rather taken with the idea and is currently looking to working up the issue, particularly in terms of the cost implications. He was pleased to have that alternative proposal put to him. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to assist the women of Australia to be able to make that choice.

The government has allocated alternative birthing funding under the national women's health program. I think it is a great shame that it is not being spent. I certainly hope that Mr Foss will be able to move quickly to approve this proposal and allow Western Australian women, in particular, to join others in Australia in having an opportunity to make a choice of birth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Trade Practices Commission's statement that it intends to block a proposed refinery merger between CSR, Mackay Sugar Co-operative Association Ltd and E.D. and F. Man. —I welcome the opportunity to respond to an opposition question that is about issues of national concern instead of being about sleaze and muckraking. Senator Boswell has not quite outlined the situation accurately. I will outline the situation as I understand it.

PARA.TAB: The Trade Practices Commission has issued a draft determination; it is not yet a final determination. The commission has indicated that, on the information presently before it, it considered that competition would be less than substantial if the venture went ahead and that the joint venture could result in higher prices. However, the process still has a way to go. I understand that a conference will be held with the applicants in a couple of weeks time and that the applicants will have the opportunity to put further information to the commission.

The Trade Practices Commission—which at least Senator Boswell would be interested in and aware of—cannot be directed by me or any other minister in relation to any individual application of the act. So the minister cannot give a direction to the Trade Practices Commission in this matter. The legislation sets down the criteria within which the commission acts and it acts independently. The parties' source of redress, if they are not happy with the decision, is appeal to the Trade Practices Tribunal and subsequently to the Federal Court.

There are some stages still to go, but the matter will be dealt with independently by the commission rather than by the minister. I agree with Senator Boswell that it is an important issue. He has raised some important facts, which I understand are already before the Trade Practices Commission, and I am sure that it will take those and other factors into account in its decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health and refers to the Medicare agreement, in particular the requirement covering the private versus public occupied bed-day ratios. My understanding is that, in so far as the Medicare agreements are concerned, because the state as a whole will still comply with the required ratios there will be no breach. I do not really believe that there is much I can do about a situation when the Medicare agreements will not be breached and will be kept.

PARA.TAB: I have asked Mr Evans to monitor that situation, because he is acutely aware that there will be some problems. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is not only the hospital in Port Augusta; there are a large number of hospitals that are suffering. PARA.TAB: In terms of who is responsible, obviously in any agreement, be it a commercial agreement between companies or an agreement between governments, both sides will try to make sure that the other side keeps its part of that agreement. We are constantly monitoring the Medicare agreements with all the states to make sure that they are being kept. I am quite worried about where those outcomes will be in a couple of states. As far as I am aware, South Australia will keep to the terms of the agreement by the ratio across the whole of the state, even if some individual hospitals go over and others go under; it averages out. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Can the minister please explain why not one cent of the government's $400,000 community education stop violence against women program has been allocated to Tasmania? Does the government consider that Tasmanian women are not worthy of support in this supposedly national program, or were the numerous proposals put forward by Tasmanian service providers not considered by the government to be of sufficient standard? What does the minister have to say to Tasmanian women who may be the victims of domestic violence and who have just been refused funding support by the government? Will the minister reconsider funding an education program in Tasmania for Tasmanian women who are victims of these shocking crimes?

—The first point is that the community education program stopping violence against women is an Australia-wide program. The education kit—that is, the posters, community education billboards, advertisements, leaflets, and so on—will be as widely available in Tasmania as it is in any part of the country. The clear message of this government's concern for stopping violence against women, assisted now with the support of non-violent men also speaking out against violence against women, will certainly be heard in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the allocation of the second part of the program—that is, the grants program to assist with this community education program—more than 400 applications were received from around the country with a total of 28 from Tasmania. There were 20 successful projects. They were selected on the basis that they best met criteria outlined in the guidelines. These criteria required that the projects have a clear community education focus—many applications contained a large service delivery focus rather than an educational one—and be state-wide or national in scope, that is, that they have a clear national potential.

Another criterion was that the project be in one of the target areas identified, namely: projects targeting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, women from non-English speaking background, or service providers. Consideration was also given to the inclusion of projects addressing both domestic violence and sexual assault; projects which met the needs of rural and isolated communities; and projects covering a range of products—such as conferences, videos, media campaigns and resource kits—particularly stressing the capacity to further the education campaign through those grants.

Tasmania was not successful with any of its projects in its application this year. That is not a measure taken against Tasmania, nor is it a measure taken against most of the other applicants who were also unsuccessful. It is a question of limited resources and making a choice between projects which meet all the criteria, demonstrate levels of excellence and have the widest capacity to extend that education campaign. As I said, it is no measure against Tasmania. Indeed, in the last round of grants, Tasmania was successful with three projects. There is no capacity to rethink or reallocate the dollars. I appreciate Tasmania's disappointment this time round but I would remind Senator Calvert that Tasmania successfully received three grants last time.

Senator Calvert should be assured that all Tasmanian people will have access to the major community education program that I launched in Sydney, particularly getting the message through posters and billboards that when it comes to violence against women there is no way that this government would regard women in Tasmania any differently from women across Australia.

So, even in this limited audiovisual sector of the industry, we have at least 20,000 jobs.

PARA.TAB: Film in particular is an inherently labour intensive industry and, therefore, it has significant capacity to make a valuable contribution to employment. The cultural contribution is the most important aspect of the reason governments support arts organisations, the film industry and others. ANSWER.PARA: Entertainment products . . . are exemplars par excellence of the commodities which will increase in economic significance under the influence of such trends . . .

It is talking about the trends of technological change. That is why so much emphasis was given in the budget to increased support for the arts. Around 31 per cent of the total federal arts budget now goes to support the film industry. Just to indicate that this is not something in our region that is uniquely recognised by the Australian government, the Singapore Minister for Information and the Arts said:
We want to make Singapore a centre for the arts, partly for its own sake and partly because we need the arts to help make us a centre for brain services.
We want talent from all over the world to meet here, to work here and to live here. We cannot work the magic without the arts.

I think there is growing recognition in most parts of the world and in most parts of Australia, if not all together here, that there is growing economic significance in the arts. Austrade has identified audiovisual as an area of significant export potential. This report by the South Australian centre for the Film Commission, the department and the screen producers is very timely and very welcome. I commend it to members and others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. PARA.TAB: This matter is a cause for concern. I am not sure of the extent to which this report picks up all those issues, but it is that philosophy, amongst others, which underpins the significance of the Australian content regulation in television and which underpins the government's assistance to the film industry through the Film Commission, Film Australia and the Film Finance Corporation.

As Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, will she now tell the Senate what she, her government and the Office of the Status of Women have done to educate both men and women as to the unacceptability of violence against children?

Secondly, the National Child Protection Council will be a very important contributor to the programs, the thinking and the community consultation for the International Year of the Family. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the minister supply figures for the amount of money that the government directly spends on the campaign to stop violence against women and the amount of money that it directly spends on any assistance to educate people as to the unacceptability of violence against children? Secondly, given that Senator Ray told us earlier today that important matters ought not to be left to the states, why does the minister think she can simply say that the government will set up a council to negotiate with the states and leave it at that?

It is the states that are the principal deliverers of services—services of matters of law, services of matters of health and services of matters of education. Where it is appropriate, what the Commonwealth has done is assume leadership. In this very important case it has assumed leadership and it has assumed a national perspective, because it realises that, despite the best intentions of states, sometimes the state prevention strategies are not sufficient.

PARA.TAB: We are moving to establish a prevention movement. It is not acceptable to consider services that deal with child abuse and child assault only after it has happened. What we are looking at is ways in which we can move to early intervention and also emphasise very strongly the prevention of child abuse. I will provide Senator Vanstone with the figures in detail for the amount of money, but the Commonwealth and states are still negotiating on the further expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day relating to a Government response to the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act.
