The answer Senator Bolkus gave, for those who did not hear it in its entirety, was `soon'. I think it was arrogant and petulant, and I think the Senate should condemn it absolutely. For the benefit of Senator Bolkus and this government, there is a convention in this place that the government respond to committee reports within 90 days. It is now over a year since this report was presented.

PARA.TAB: The background to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act is a long and tortuous one. I first raised matters about the complaints my office received about five years ago. I initially sought to have a Senate select committee inquiry, but the government repeatedly told me that nothing was wrong with the Family Law Act and the family law system and that there had been sufficient reviews of the whole area of divorce in Australia.

I enlisted the assistance of Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats. He and I got our heads together. We bashed them against a brick wall for a while, because the government would not listen to us. We persisted and, in December 1990, the government finally and reluctantly agreed to such an inquiry but insisted that it be a joint inquiry. The committee received a total of 1,031 submissions. That is why I am so interested and why the minister was arrogant in his reply today. He hardly rose to his feet to say that the government's response would be released soon. People throughout Australia are today continuing to write to every electorate office around Australia with complaints about the Family Law Act.

The inquiry was effectively chaired by Senator McKiernan. I have said in this place before that he did a fantastic job. We took evidence in every capital city as well as in a lot of regional centres. We produced a report a year ago as a result of those thousand-odd submissions. In my opinion, our 120 recommendations reflected a balanced, definitive analysis of the Family Law Act in Australia. It was a genuine attempt to assess the weaknesses in the present legislation and, I suggest, to offer appropriate and workable changes to the law.

Many people throughout Australia, both within and outside the legislative process, spent countless hours on the report's preparation. It was eagerly awaited. I believe they feel that the system has let them down. They now obviously realise that this government has let them down by not coming back and telling us something better than what the minister said today—that we will get the reply to that report soon.

I took steps earlier today to inform the minister, Senator Bolkus, about what I was going to ask him. When I saw him in the centre of Parliament House this morning I gave him the import of what I was going to ask. I think he could have done a lot more for the people of Australia. I told him that I did not want to political point score; I still do not want to.

Senator Bolkus sent me a note at the end of question time that Mr Lavarch hopes to be able to respond by the end of the year or by January but that he is not yet in a position to give a formal date. At least he could have told the Senate that publicly rather than just saying that the government would respond soon.

I believe that the Labor government has today shown its true commitment to the reform of the Family Law Act. It has abandoned those who served on the committee. More importantly, it has abandoned those tens of thousands of Australians who are counting on us to do something about an act that has not worked as well as it should have. I am ashamed of this government's answer today and I am appalled by its apathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Needless to say, I do not agree with all the remarks Senator Brownhill has just directed to the Senate. I thank him and agree with the points he made about the work of the committee—
—And the way you chaired it. You did a very good job.

—I thank Senator Brownhill. The committee presented its report to this chamber and to the other place on 24 November 1992, which is exactly 12 months ago on Wednesday of next week. By any standards, that is a long time for the government to take to respond to a report. I too have concerns about the length of time the government has taken to respond and I have raised those concerns directly with the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan). My concerns were allayed somewhat when the full details of the reasons for the delay were put to us.
—Why didn't the minister tell us that today?

—Perhaps it would have been useful if the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, had been in a position to put those remarks to the chamber today. I did not know that the question was going to be asked. I also do not know the content of Senator Bolkus's advice from the Attorney or from the Minister for Justice.

PARA.TAB: Let us reflect on what has happened in the 12 months since the report was presented to the parliament on 24 November 1992. In the intervening period there was an election. That meant that, for a time, the effective work of government was not proceeded with. Through an anomaly that occurred prior to the election, the election of the Attorney-General was delayed by over one month. There was a caretaker minister, Mr Kerr, but I think it was almost May before we had a portfolio minister directly in charge of and responsible for the Attorney-General's affairs. That obviously caused some delay in developing a response to what I consider to be a very good and worthwhile report.

The report is receiving detailed consideration by all concerned. The government, when it responds to reports of the nature of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, does not just take the report and make decisions on its own. It tests those views with a number of bodies and organisations, including the Family Law Council and the Family Court. It seeks responses, and those responses are tested again and again.

On reflection, I believe that the delay in responding to the report of the committee will probably be very beneficial. It is important that, in a major review of the Family Law Act, which has been in operation now for some 18 years, this time we get it right. My information is that there will be a response by the minister in the next two-week sitting of the Senate, and in a somewhat shorter time in the House of Representatives. I do not have a detailed date, as probably Minister Bolkus did not have a detailed date, to give in response to Senator Brownhill's question.

I expect detailed responses to each and every one of the 120 recommendations in the report. I do not expect that the government will agree to each and every one of those 120 recommendations, but I do hope each of them will have received the benefit of that 12-month period of deliberation on this aspect of the report. I welcome Senator Brownhill's raising the matter. It is not something that I, as the former chairman of the committee, had forgotten about. Indeed, I have been pressing the matter along and, while I have a concern about the delay, I hope the government has used that 12-month period to undertake a full and deep consideration of the report and that, when it does respond, it will give detailed consideration to the benefit of all Australians, not just those that end up before the Family Court of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to the granting of arts fellowships.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue I raised in question time could not be more serious. It raises grave doubts about the propriety of the Prime Minister of Australia. Yesterday the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) stated that the awarding of these fellowships, ironically known as the Keatings, `is resolved at arm's length from the government'. The Prime Minister's office is quoted in yesterday's Courier-Mail as saying that the grant recipients were decided by a judging panel appointed by the Australia Council with absolutely no input from the Prime Minister. I totally disagree with that.

PARA.TAB: In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald in May 1989, Bob Evans said in relation to Mr Keating:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . supervised the recruitment of the seven members of the fellowship advisory panel, demanding that the nominees be non-bureaucrats with a working knowledge of the arts in Australia.
He went on to say:
Mr Keating has also stipulated how the panel is to relate to the Australia Council.
He has deliberately chosen to keep the fellowships at arm's length from the council.
It might be at arm's length from the council, but it is not at arm's length from the government. Mr Keating is quoted in the article as saying:
I do not want this thing to be part of the Australia Council because it is stale.
Later in the article, Bob Evans stated:
Mr Keating is emphatic that there should be no bureaucratic monitoring of the fellowship recipients.
He went on to say:
He vetoed a provision which would have made the award subject to reasonable progress in completing the planning project or activity.

That is the sort of thing that goes on with the Churchill fellowships; recipients have to report in. The two-time winner, Geoffrey Tozer, has admitted that he was a catalyst for the awards. There is also no doubt that he is a personal friend of the Prime Minister. The question is: who chose Mr Tozer?

PARA.TAB: I have been informed by the Australia Council that one Paul Keating attended the meeting in 1989 at which the fellowships were decided, including the first fellowship for Mr Tozer. Who was on the advisory panel, the recruitment of which was supervised by Mr Keating? Who were the music representatives? One was Mr Ross Gengos from Abels Music in Manuka, a close personal friend of the Prime Minister, the man who has the Prime Minister's ear over CD copyright. The Prime Minister opened Mr Gengos's record shop. Mr Gengos's Abels also produced a record titled `Geoffrey Tozer in Concert' in 1987. Mr Gengos was still on the committee this year for Mr Tozer's second fellowship.

The other music representative on the panel in 1989 was Mr Reuben Fineberg. I am led to believe that Mr Fineberg is Mr Tozer's agent. I am told by people in the music world that he has taken a keen professional interest in Mr Tozer's career for some years. We are not questioning Mr Tozer's ability as a pianist. We recognise that our artists need to be rewarded. We want to make sure that the due process of those rewards is correct and proper and is seen to be correct and proper by the community and by the arts community.

In his submission for the first fellowship, what did Mr Tozer say he would do with his money? According to Wilson in the Sunday Herald-Sun in July 1991, Mr Tozer said that the money would be used to promote concerts by lesser-known composers, to establish a house of excellence, and to provide master classes for advanced students. He was going to use the money to turn St Benedicts Convent in Queanbeyan into a music school.

I am informed that $200,000 of the original grant was spent on buying the building. Who was his guiding light in this project? Mr Keating. Who reportedly went with him and bought the building? Mr Keating. Who regularly inspected the work? Mr Keating. Who lent a hand when he was in exile on the back bench? Mr Keating. Where is the music school? It does not exist. The building is up for sale and will be auctioned on 27 November. Mr Tozer received a further $325,000 in an unprecedented second fellowship. The guidelines for fellowship state:

SPEECH.PARA: In exceptional circumstances a new Fellowship may be granted at the end of the first. This could occur if a Fellowship proved to be especially rewarding for the artist and the community at large.

Of the 175 applicants, there were nine winners. Why, in the circumstances that I have outlined, did Mr Tozer get an unprecedented second fellowship? Mr Keating must immediately answer this and all the other serious questions that relate to this affair.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to comment on an answer given yesterday by Senator McMullan in relation to taxpayers' rights. I was denied the opportunity to comment on this yesterday because of a lapse in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks about not only the extraordinary interview on Lateline last night with Mr Conrad Black but also the even more extraordinary response from the Prime Minister this morning. What Mr Black essentially said last night was that in the run-up to the last federal election, to be precise in January 1992, in a meeting at Kirribilli House, Mr Keating indicated that if the Fairfax newspapers were balanced in their coverage the Prime Minister would entertain an application from Mr Black to raise the foreign ownership limits from 15 per cent to 25 per cent. In the event, that actually occurred after the election. There was a bit of toing and froing. Mr Dawkins, as Treasurer, was opposed to it, but it happened.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it, new lows were reached in Australian politics because for the first time Mr Black was alleging that a government had made a decision in relation to foreign ownership not on any national interest criteria but specifically at the request of a media proprietor. It is one thing to acknowledge that media proprietors would like to be more in control than they are at present, if they do not already have 100 per cent control, and there is nothing particularly unusual about Conrad Black pushing his case in the way that he did.

For Mr Keating to then not only entertain the idea but effectively enter into an agreement to provide a political quid pro quo is utterly extraordinary. That is why we all waited with bated breath to hear his response. On The World Today, Mr Dawkins was at great pains to say, `Well, that's what Mr Black says, but that's only his side of the story and one has to hear the other side'. He was asked whether he stood by his press release of 20 April this year in which he said that the government will not countenance further increases in the permitted level of foreign involvement in mass circulation newspapers. He said that the government did.

The relevance of that is that Mr Black was also asserting that when he saw Mr Keating earlier this week he asked Mr Keating whether he was prepared to go higher. Mr Black said last night that we can never get too much of a good thing and, as far as he was concerned, he would like at least 50 per cent but certainly he would like somewhere between 25 per cent and 50 per cent. In other words, he was putting an ambit claim on the table.

Mr Black had asked Mr Keating for his reading of what was feasible and how things looked. Mr Black said, `Mr Keating said that it would be premature to do anything at this point but that if I had some suggestions I should make them and he would be prepared to consider any suggestions'. In other words, Mr Black was again saying that the Prime Minister indicated his willingness to further increase the foreign ownership limit to accommodate Mr Black. Those are extraordinary allegations.

We have just had a door-stop in Seattle by the Prime Minister in which he confirmed the accuracy of those reports. In many ways, I think he was boasting about it. His answers were breathtaking in their arrogance and amorality. When asked what he thought of the coverage of the Fairfax papers in the run-up to the last election, he said that he thought they were reasonable. We do not have to be too smart to work out what Mr Keating had in mind when he said that he wanted balanced coverage. That was code for saying that he expected that there would be little or no criticism of the ALP in general and himself in particular in the run-up to the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you read the Fairfax press?
—I certainly did. The government got a very good run. Senator Schacht does not need to take my word for it because today in Seattle Mr Keating said that the reporting was reasonable.
—He also gets roundly criticised from time to time. They all predicted the defeat of the Labor government endlessly.
—We are not talking about editorials. I hope that Senator Schacht appreciates the further significance of what was said last night.
—Are you saying that people like Geoff Kitney fixed their stories?

—I am not saying that Kitney fixed his stories. I am saying that the coverage of the Fairfax papers in the run-up to the last election was much more favourable than might otherwise have been the case. Mr Keating, himself a long time critic of the Sydney Morning Herald in particular—Senator Schacht well knows the sort of frothing at the mouth by the Prime Minister about what he believes of those journalists—said that the coverage was reasonable.
—Tell me which journalists were biased in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Financial Review and the Age.
—Has Senator Schacht finished? We have got 25 minutes. I hope that I will be allowed to have my say because he will get his say afterwards.
—We want to go home.

—Senator Schacht will not be going home if he carries on with that nonsense, because I am not responding to those sorts of matters any more than I believe he would and any more than I believe that Mr Keating would in public.

PARA.TAB: The point of the proposition is that Mr Keating himself recognises that the coverage was reasonable. That comes from a long-time critic. Senator Schacht obviously has not heard what Mr Keating said in Seattle; Senator Schacht is a bit slow on the uptake. The proposition is that Mr Black said last night that Mr Keating said he wanted balanced coverage. Mr Keating was asked this morning whether he agreed that the coverage was balanced and he said it was reasonable. Mr Keating was asked whether he was prepared to entertain any further applications, and he said yes. He was asked, `Who are you to decide what is fair and accurate? TALK.START.PARA: —And he is responsible to the people accordingly in the next election.
—Senator Schacht accepts that, does he?
—Absolutely.

—What we have now got from Senator Schacht is yet another confirmation that the national interest is synonymous with the ALP's interests. In other words, Senator Schacht supports the Prime Minister when he says to Fairfax, `You're on trial. You get it right. You don't criticise us. If Senator Schacht cannot tell the difference between right and wrong, he is no better than the Prime Minister whose only political creed is new cronyism, who believes and seems to flaunt it, that the more he can impose his will on others, the more he will prosper.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that Mr Keating is a classic, living confirmation of Lord Acton's dictum that power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely. The arrogance of this man is breathtaking. It is utterly outrageous to be out there claiming that the government will allow an increase in foreign ownership if the press gets it right by the government's standards. In other words, Mr Keating is saying, `You do it my way and I'll fix it up in your way'. That is preposterous and outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon I cast some doubt about the strength of certain rights available to taxpayers under taxation law, especially those that were outlined by Senator McMullan in his response yesterday. The nature of the response effectively rejected the need for either a taxpayers' bill of rights, as advocated by the Taxation Institute of Australia, or a charter of rights, as recommended by the recent report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, report No. 326. Therefore, I seek the leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard a letter from the Taxation Institute of Australia of today's date, outlining arguments for a taxpayers' bill of rights, together with the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report No. 326, 13.18.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter and recommendations read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALIA
19 November 1993
Senator John Watson
Parliament House
Canberra 2600
Dear Senator Watson
RE: THE ARGUMENTS FOR A TAXPAYERS BILL OF RIGHTS

I have read press reports today that would indicate that members of the Government in the Senate are of the view that there is no pressing need for a taxpayer's bill of rights to formally protect the rights of taxpayers. The Taxation Institute does not agree with this contention. Rather, it is of the view that, with the pending extension of the self assessment system now is the most appropriate time to specifically legislate to protect and enshrine the rights of taxpayers and the duties and obligations of the ATO in administering taxing Acts.

Senator McMullan has stated that rights such as the right to be treated equally under the law, to object against an assessment, to rely on a private Ruling, to seek an explanation, to be represented, the right to privacy and to have documents remain confidential when they are prepared by a lawyer are all presently enshrined in the law. In some of the examples provided, there is some limited protection provided in the taxing Acts. However, it is submitted, that in many of the examples cited by Senator McMullan, "these rights are not clear, are not well understood by either taxpayers or the ATO and are limited in nature. Additionally, there are many examples of areas where there is little or no protection given to taxpayers, which should be the subject of specifically legislated rights.

For example, the right to object does not extend to a penalty of less than 20% of the tax payable. A specific right enabling a taxpayer to object and appeal against decisions made against them by the ATO in respect of actions taken during the course of an examination of their affairs or in respect of any determination of their liability to tax, would greatly extend a taxpayers rights in this regard.

The right of a taxpayer to obtain confidential information, should not be limited solely to information obtained from a lawyer. It should extend to advice obtained from any recognised adviser in respect to the tax affairs of the taxpayer. There is currently limited administrative recognition of this right. However, it is submitted that this right should be specifically enshrined in legislation.

There is currently a right for a taxpayer to be represented by a legal adviser. This was confirmed in Dunkel v DFCT 91 ATC 4142. However, taxpayers do not presently have a right to have a non legally qualified adviser present. This is obviously unsatisfactory since many taxpayers obtain tax advice from accountants and tax agents who are not otherwise legally qualified. Consequently, this right needs to be specifically expanded.

An example of a right which is not presently enshrined in the legislation is the right to reasonable certainty. This would mean that, where the law was unclear, a taxpayer would be given the benefit of the doubt. This was once an accepted rule of interpretation for taxing statutes. This right should operate to require a finding in a taxpayers favour if the law was so uncertain as to not enable a taxpayer to ascertain with reasonable certainty his or her liability with respect to particular activities engaged in or proposed to be engaged in.

It is submitted that an important right which is not dealt with in any taxing statute is the right to expect equal treatment under the law and by the ATO. This, of course would not mean that a taxpayer's particular circumstances could not be taken into consideration. However, it would mean that all taxpayers would obtain equal treatment under the law, which is particularly important in relation to the exercise of discretions by the Commissioner. This would mean that a situation such as that which arose in David Jones Finance and Investments Pty Ltd v FCT 91 ATC 4315, would not arise.

There are many other instances where there is a need to develop and formally recognise taxpayer's rights and the "Taxpayer's Bill of Rights" drafted by the Taxation Institute discusses many of these in some detail. The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody in a speech to the National Institute of Accountants on 4 November 1993 referred to the need for the recognition of such rights. It is strongly submitted by the Taxation Institute that the only way such rights can be properly recognised is via a formal Taxpayer's Bill of Rights.
Yours faithfully
Annamaria Carey

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this place to raise a matter which has just been brought to my attention by way of a press release received from Mr Bob Gardini, who is, of course, the solicitor acting on behalf of two former employees at the Lodge. Mr Gardini's clients—honourable senators may remember—were formerly housekeepers at the Lodge who had had their employment terminated in a rather unsatisfactory manner. Their employment was terminated when they were phoned on a Sunday evening and told not to bother coming in to work on the Monday and that, if they did attempt to go in to work on the Monday, they would be turned away by the guards.

PARA.TAB: I will now send over to Senator Sherry copies of two documents. I intend to read portions of one of them, which is the letter addressed to Mr Gardini's firm by Mr R.D. Beale, acting secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Of course, this has come to me via Mr Gardini's press release. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your letter of 10 November 1993 to Dr Keating requesting reasons for the termination of your clients' employment at the Lodge, references going beyond the Certificates of Service already provided, an ex gratia payment and reimbursement of legal costs.

Concerning reasons for the decisions, I draw your attention to paragraph (y) of Schedule 2 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 which excludes "decisions relating to. . . employing, or terminating the employment of staff, under the Member of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984" from the requirements of section 13 of the AD(JR) Act. This exclusion reflects the policy underlying the MOP(S) Act that members and senators (including the Prime Minister on whose behalf Ms Tinney acted in relation to your clients) should have complete discretion in the employment of their personal staff.
This has angered Mr Gardini and it has angered his clients. This afternoon he has put out a press release in which he says:
GOVERNMENT ATTEMPTS TO GAG HOUSEKEEPERS

I will quote a couple of portions of this press release. I note that in the press release, on behalf of his clients, Mr Gardini says that he has been instructed to say that they are disappointed that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has declined to give reasons why they were dismissed. It says:

In view of the comments made by an officer before a Senate Committee we do not consider it as acceptable for the Department to hide behind the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Certain allegations have been made about the circumstances of our dismissal which are inconsistent with the issuing of a Certificate of Service by the Department. Because of the public airing of the circumstances of our dismissal we sought assurances from the Department that our service at the Lodge had been satisfactory so that we could seek alternative employment without having unsubstantiated allegations hanging over our heads.

We are shocked by the statement by the Acting Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that it would be in our "best interests for there to be no further publicity on the matter." This in our view is an attempt to silence us.
The press release goes on to make further statements. In fact, it calls for an independent inquiry into the circumstances of the housekeepers' dismissal and their request for compensation.

PARA.TAB: The important point is that there are provisions under the relevant act, but in the estimates committee public servants sought to make what appear to be wholly unsubstantiated allegations against the two housekeepers—allegations which are not supported by the facts and certainly are not consistent with the issuing of certificates of service. In spite of these allegations having been made, under the privilege of the Senate, the government attempts to rely—and the Prime Minister attempts to rely—on the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. He is hiding behind the skirt of legislation which was intended for something completely different.

At the same time, the Prime Minister has absolutely no qualms about having public servants come into an estimates committee hearing and attack the two housekeepers, who could not defend themselves, and make all these baseless allegations. It is my understanding that it was not their fault—there were just understandable reasons why their employment was terminated. They do deserve to be treated in a proper fashion. I am as infuriated as Mr Gardini is that the Prime Minister thinks that the appropriate way to deal with his domestic staff is to sack them in this fashion—after all, staff deserve to be decently treated—to use public servants to malign them before a Senate estimates committee, to refuse to even give them the opportunity of having a reference, and to leave this hanging over their heads.

Mr Keating claims to represent the working people of this country. I think that this is particularly disgusting behaviour. I do not think it is the sort of behaviour that any employer should indulge in. We have already seen how, when they went to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to get an explanation as to why their employment was terminated, they were intimidated by having sections of the Crimes Act read to them, including official secrets provisions—and now there is this carry-on.

Mr Gardini and his clients are quite right in their indignation at the way they have been treated. I take this opportunity today to call on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet—indeed, to call on Mr Keating himself—to start acting in a reasonable and proper way towards these people. They have put in good service and are asking for only the most fundamental of dignities, which is to get a reference attesting to their good service.

They have had to go through all of this. I do not think the Prime Minister intends to give them a reference now. But there was absolutely no need for it to come to this. It is Mr Keating's fault—nobody else's. There was, I understand, a perfectly reasonable explanation as to why they are no longer employed. They are, I understand, very good staff and it is unreasonable that they should be maligned in this fashion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
